episodes.description: Anthropologist Hugh Raffles ruminates on human-insect relationships around the world in his new book Insectopedia. Japanese insect boys, Chinese fighting crickets, insect minds, insect music...
episodes.title: Hugh Raffles: Insectopedia

episodes.subtitle: Tango in music and dance.
episodes.description: We consider the music and dance that captured the hearts of millions. Guests include tango historians Donald Cohen and Christine Denniston, and members of the Santa Cruz tango community. Show originally broadcast April, 2009.
episodes.title: What's So Special About Tango?

episodes.subtitle: Journalist Gabriel Thompson on his book: "Working in the Shadows: A Year of Doing the Jobs Most American's Won't Do"
episodes.description: Writer Gabriel Thompson went undercover to learn first-hand about the tough low-wage jobs done mostly by immigrants in America. He harvested lettuce in Arizona, toiled in a slaughterhouse in Alabama and did low-end restaurant jobs in Manhattan. He describes his year of working strenuously, and what he learned about immigrant labor.
episodes.title: Gabriel Thompson: Working in the Shadows

episodes.subtitle: Science writer Anil Ananthaswamy reports on some of the world's most advanced, and remote, physics labs
episodes.description: In recent years, physics theory has gotten way ahead of the evidence. Now, researchers are going to extremes to figure out what’s true and what isn’t. They’ve launched a set of hugely ambitious experiments in some of the most forbidding places on Earth, from the South Pole to Himalayan mountaintops. Physics writer Anil Ananthaswamy travelled to these remote laboratories, and he tells us what he saw.
episodes.title: The Edge of Physics: Anil Ananthaswamy

episodes.subtitle: Cognitive scientist and record producer Daniel Levitin discusses the neuroscience of music.
episodes.description: A tune-filled celebration and cerebration with neuroscientist, musician and record producer Daniel Levitin, author of "This is Your Brain on Music." Originally broadcast in 2007.
episodes.title: The Musical Brain: Neuroscientist Dan Levitin

episodes.subtitle: Evolutionary Biologist Barry Sinervo: Adventures in Lizardland.
episodes.description: What Jane Goodall was to chimps, biologist Barry Sinervo is to lizards. He's spent the last 20 years studying lizards in the wild, gaining remarkable insights into the workings of evolution, social behavior and cooperation. He shares his discoveries, along with some very funny lizard stories.
episodes.title: Adventures in Lizardland: Evolutionary Biologist Barry Sinervo

episodes.subtitle: Painter Richard Mayhew discusses his life and work
episodes.description: Noted landscape painter Richard Mayhew discusses his life and work, including his childhood in a mixed African American and Native American community, joining the New York art scene at the height of the abstract expressionist movement, his second career as a jazz singer and helping to organize African-American artists in the 1960s.
episodes.title: Painter Richard Mayhew--A Life in Art

episodes.subtitle: writer Terry Castle discusses her latest irreverent and wickedly funny essay collection.
episodes.description: Terry Castle takes on her own and others' self-deceptions in her latest collection of hilarious, brutally honest essays, "The Professor and Other Writings." Targets include sex, romance and youthful infatuations. She and Robert do their best to burst as many bubbles as possible.
episodes.title: Essayist Terry Castle

episodes.subtitle: Ushering in the psychedelic age at Harvard.
episodes.description: Fifty years ago, a group of Harvard faculty began experimenting with psychoactive drugs and helped turn on a generation. Robert looks back on a defining cultural moment with Don Lattin, author of "The Harvard Psychedelic Club," and with Harvard alumnus Paul Lee, who took part in the experiments.
episodes.title: The Harvard Psychedelic Club

episodes.subtitle: Philosopher/novelist Rebecca Goldstein on religion and belief
episodes.description: Philosopher/Novelist Rebecca Goldstein discusses her latest book, "36 Arguments for the Existence of God: A Work of Fiction." She and Robert consider the case for and against religion.
episodes.title: Rebecca Goldstein V. God

episodes.subtitle: Partners In Health Brings Medical Care to Haiti
episodes.description: In the aftermath of the Port-Au-Prince earthquake, the medical organization Partners in Health has played a key role bringing emergency aid to Haiti. On this edition of the 7th Avenue Project, Robert's 2003 interview with writer Tracy Kidder, discussing Partners in Health, its work in Haiti and its founder, Dr. Paul Farmer. Farmer was the subject of Kidder's best-selling book "Mountains Beyond Mountains."
episodes.title: Partners In Health Brings Medical Care to Haiti

episodes.subtitle: Cartoonist/war correspondent Joe Sacco talks about his career and his latest book, "Footnotes in Gaza"
episodes.description: Over the last two decades, Joe Sacco has helped invent a new genre: comic-book journalism. He's reported from Sarajevo during the Bosnian War and from the Palestinian Territories during the two Intifadas. His latest book is "Footnotes in Gaza." In today's show, he talks about his career, his experiences in the Palestinian Territories and the roots of conflict in Gaza.
episodes.title: Cartoon Journalist Joe Sacco

episodes.subtitle: American studies scholar Forrest Robinson examines the truth behind the Mark Twain persona
episodes.description: What Mark Twain's writing tells us about him and about America. Twain scholar Forrest Robinson looks behind the mask of America's favorite humorist and finds a troubled conscience, haunted by history.
episodes.title: The Real Mark Twain

episodes.subtitle: The Beat Within: voices and writing from juvenile hall. Featuring incarcerated youths and workshop leaders Dennis Morton and Jill Wolfson
episodes.description: "The Beat Within" is a weekly magazine that collects writings by teens in California juvenile halls. Host Robert Pollie talks to kids in Santa Cruz Juvenile Hall who participate in the program, and to Beat Within workshop leaders Jill Wolfson and Dennis Morton.
episodes.title: The Beat Within--Voices from Juvie

episodes.subtitle: Armenian folksinger Hasmik Harutyunyan and the Kitka women's vocal ensemble sing and discuss traditional Armenian songs.
episodes.description: In this end-of-the-year musical special, we put 2009 to bed with some exquisite, ethereal lullabies and other songs from the famed Armenian singer Hasmik Harutyunyan and the Kitka women's vocal ensemble. Along with the music, Hasmik and Shira Cion of Kitka discuss the tragic history and haunting music of Armenia with host Robert Pollie.
episodes.title: Armenian Lullabies and Songs of Longing

episodes.subtitle: After 12 years wrongly imprisoned, exoneree Rick Walker seeks restitution.
episodes.description: Rick Walker spent 12 years in California prisons for a murder he didn't commit. In part 2 of this 2-part series, Walker talks about his life after prison, and film makers Gwen Essegian and Mark Ligon discuss their new documentary about Walker's fight to get restitution for the years he lost. Also, Lola Vollen, director of the Life After Exoneration project, on the plight of exonerees nationwide.
episodes.title: After Exoneration: The Rick Walker Story, Pt 2 of 2

episodes.subtitle: Exoneree Rick walker on his wrongful conviction and 12 years behind bars
episodes.description: Rick Walker spent 12 years in California prisons for a murder he didn't commit. In part I of a multipart series he talks about his conviction, his years behind bars and his release.
episodes.title: When Justice Fails: The Rick Walker Story, Pt 1 of 2

episodes.subtitle: Writers Tracy Kidder and Andrew Sean Greer discuss private struggles in a time of war
episodes.description: Two interviews from the archives: Tracy Kidder discusses his 2006 memoir, "My Detachment," about the year he spent as a young army lieutenant in Vietnam. Novelist Andrew Sean Greer from 2008, on his most recent work: "The Story of A Marriage."
episodes.title: Private Wars: Tracy Kidder and Andrew Sean Greer

episodes.subtitle: Nobel prizewinning physicist Frank Wilczek on the fabric of the universe.
episodes.description: The stuff the universe is made of. Nobel Prize-winning physicist Frank Wilczek talks to Robert about the fundamental ingredients of physical reality. Where mass comes from, why empty space isn't, and other marvels of modern physics explained.
episodes.title: The Bottom of Things

episodes.subtitle: The Genome 10K Project: Mapping the genes of 10,000 animals
episodes.description: Building the genome zoo. In the most ambitious effort of its type ever attempted, scientists are hoping to map the genes of 10,000 different animals. Proponents say the "Genome 10K project" will provide vast new insights into the biology, evolution and preservation of species. KUSP's Robert Pollie talks to project coordinator David Haussler of UC Santa Cruz.
episodes.title: Building The Genome Zoo

episodes.subtitle: Fado: Songs from the Soul of Portugal
episodes.description: The soul-stirring Portuguese music known as Fado. Robert discusses and listens to the art of Fado with Donald Cohen, author of "Fado Portuges." Featuring music by Mariza, Caminé, Amalia Rodrigues and more.
episodes.title: All About Fado

episodes.subtitle: Dr. Ashis Brahma on medicine and human rights.
episodes.description: Physician and human rights activist Ashis Brahma of the Phoenix Global Health Foundation talks about practicing medicine in conflict zones and refugee camps.
episodes.title: Medicine at the Extremes

episodes.subtitle: Physicist Geoffrey West on the mathematics of life and death
episodes.description: A theoretical physicist searches for the universal laws of life. Geoffrey West explains some simple mathematical rules that he says may explain everything from the length of our lives to the health of our cities.
episodes.title: Life by the Numbers

episodes.subtitle: A life in comics: Art Spiegelman on his art and career.
episodes.description: Comics artist Art Spiegelman discusses "Breakdowns," the recent book collecting his work from the 1970's, and looks back on his life in cartooning and comics, from skin mags and Garbage Pail Kids to Maus and the New Yorker.
episodes.title: A Mirror Held Up to Spiegelman

episodes.subtitle: Coming to grips with tragedy and loss: Tracy Kidder and Rebecca Solnit
episodes.description: How people cope with calamity. Pulitzer prizewinner Tracy Kidder discusses his new book, "Strength in What Remains," about an African refugee fleeing ethnic violence. And social critic Rebecca Solnit talks about the response of ordinary people to the Loma Prieta earthquake, hurricane Katrina and other natural disasters.
episodes.title: After Disaster

episodes.subtitle: Looking different: Three stories of facial disfigurement and reconstructive surgery.
episodes.description: Three people whose faces were altered by illness or injury talk about self-image, the meaning of beauty, and the realities of reconstructive surgery. David Roche is an inspirational speaker and humorist. Gina Butchin works to raise awareness of facial difference. Louise Ashby is an actress and writer. They speak to host Robert Pollie.
episodes.title: What's In A Face

episodes.subtitle: Art, authenticity, race and identity mix it up in the music of the acclaimed singer-songwriter known as Stew. He discusses his musical "Passing Strange," now out in a screen version from Spike Lee.
episodes.description: Art, authenticity, race and identity mix it up in the music of the acclaimed singer-songwriter known as Stew. He discusses his musical "Passing Strange," now out in a screen version from Spike Lee.
episodes.title: The Music of "Stew"

episodes.subtitle: It's alive! Biochemist and astrobiologist David Deamer describes how life may have begun on Earth, perhaps with a little help from outer space.
episodes.description: It's alive! Biochemist and astrobiologist David Deamer describes how life may have begun on Earth, perhaps with a little help from outer space.
episodes.title: The Origins of Life on Earth

episodes.subtitle: Film maker Curt Worden discusses his documentary about Jack Kerouac's novel"Big Sur." Also, writer Robert Sullivan reflects on cross-country car trips.
episodes.description: Film maker Curt Worden discusses his documentary about Jack Kerouac's novel"Big Sur." Also, writer Robert Sullivan reflects on cross-country car trips.
episodes.title: One Fast Move or I'm Gone

episodes.subtitle: Psychologist Alison Gopnik on the surprisingly advanced thinking of young children; Joshua Klein on the remarkable intelligence of crows.
episodes.description: Developmental psychologist Alison Gopnik has spent decades studying the minds of infants and young children. Her conclusion: babies are smarter, more aware and more caring than scientists previously realized. Also, inventor Joshua Klein on the surprising intelligence of crows.
episodes.title: The Philosophical Baby

episodes.subtitle: Two heirs to large family fortunes talk about their own experiences of wealth and economic inequality in America
episodes.description: Two American heirs who grew up wealthy question their good fortune and now advocate greater economic equality. They discuss their own experiences of wealth and the distribution of wealth in the country.
episodes.title: Born Rich, Wondering Why

episodes.subtitle: Environmentalist John Francis describes his two-decade pilgrimage on foot and in silence across the US
episodes.description: For two decades, environmental activist John Francis travelled America on foot while keeping a vow of silence. Along the way, he got to know a side of himself and this country that few experience. He describes his pilgrimage to host Robert Pollie
episodes.title: Planetwalker--The Pilgrimage of John Francis

episodes.subtitle: Zen Center abbot Steve Stückey and activist doctor Patch on the limits of materialism
episodes.description: In his ongoing look at wealth in America, host Robert Pollie gets an alternative view from Zen abbot Steve Stückey and humanitarian doctor/clown Patch Adams.
episodes.title: Wealth and the Limits of Materialism

episodes.subtitle: Two master percussionists share their artistry: Orchestral percussionis Galen Lemmon of the Cabrillo Festival and Afro-Cuban drummer Michael Spiro
episodes.description: Orchestral percussionist Galen Lemmon shares some of the sounds of this year's Cabrillo Festival of Contemporary Music. Featuring marimba, vibes, steel drums, timpani, even a tuned anvil. Then, sacred drums: a visit with Afro-Cuban Batá drummer Michael Spiro.
episodes.title: Percussion Takes Center Stage

episodes.subtitle: Nobel laureate Robert Laughlin argues against reductionism in physics; super conductor Marin Alsop talks about leading the Cabrillo Festival
episodes.description: More than the sum of the parts. Nobel prizewinning physicist Robert Laughlin says nature can't always be reduced to its individual components. Plus, Maestra Marin Alsop of the Cabrillo Festival of Contemporary Music
episodes.title: Against Reductionism

episodes.subtitle: Stories from the RSVP project, an innovative anti-violence program in the San Francisco jails.
episodes.description: Criminal justice reformer Sunny Schwartz discusses the Resolve to Stop the Violence Project (RSVP) in the San Francisco jails. Plus, Ramon Garcia, former jail inmate and RSVP facilitator, describes how the program changed his life.
episodes.title: Unlearning Violence--Sunny Schwartz

episodes.subtitle: Economist Russ Roberts on wealth, its creation and destruction
episodes.description: Economist Russ Roberts about the nature of wealth, how it's created and destroyed, and whether economics really is a science.
episodes.title: Wealth and How to Destroy It

episodes.subtitle: New movie "Soul Power" commemorates "Zaire 74" concert; history of the classic African song, "Masanga"
episodes.description: A new film commemorates a legendary 1974 concert that brought together many of the greats of African, Latin and African-American music in Kinshasa, Zaire. Robert talks to filmmaker Geoffrey Levy-Hinte about the concert and the film, called "Soul Power." Plus, "Masanga": the story of a classic African song.
episodes.title: The Other Rumble in The Jungle

episodes.subtitle: Evolution, as reconstructed through fossils and DNA.
episodes.description: Paleontologist Neil Shubin describes how scientists are reconstructing the history of life from fossils and DNA, how genes shape bodies and what we have in common with fruit flies.
episodes.title: Neil Shubin on Fish, Evolution and Us

episodes.subtitle: Iran's 1979 revolution and the "Green Revolution" compared. Featuring Nahid Sarvestani and Naveed Mansouri.
episodes.description: Iranian film maker Nahid Sarvestani describes her involvement in the Iranian revolution 30 years ago and discusses her latest documentary, "The Queen and I." Then, Iranian-American student Naveed Mansouri talks about Iran's "Green Revolution" and the role of social networking technologies.
episodes.title: Iran, Then and Now

episodes.subtitle: Writer Mat Johnson talks about growing up as a black boy who looked white. Then, Yiddish Punk with Daniel Kahn and the Painted Bird
episodes.description: Writer Mat Johnson talks about growing up as a black boy who looked white. Then, Yiddish makes a comeback in the punk klezmer songs of Daniel Kahn and the Painted Bird.
episodes.title: Going Incognegro; Yiddishkeit 2.0

episodes.subtitle: Jonathan Ames on his graphic novel, "The Alcoholic" and his new HBO series "Bored to Death."
episodes.description: WriterJonathan Ames talks about his graphic novel, "The Alcoholic," his upcoming HBO comedy series and his double life as public and private figure. Plus: Short and Sweet: the Big Sur International Short Film Series.
episodes.title: The Double Life is Twice As Good

episodes.subtitle: Wall Street Journal reporter Robert Frank on the super-rich and the recession; where to stash your gold
episodes.description: Robert Frank of the Wall Street Journal on the impact of the economic crisis on the upper upper crust. Also: where to stash your gold bullion: Lynel Berryhill of Brown Safe Manufacturing, purveyor of luxury vaults and safes.
episodes.title: Wealth Ain't What it Used to Be

episodes.subtitle: Linguist Geoffrey Pullum on grammar misconceptions; the stability of language.
episodes.description: Geoffrey Pullum, linguist and author of "The Cambridge Grammar of the English Language," discusses the grammar wars, common misconceptions about English and whether we really can talk to the animals.
episodes.title: Ask a Linguist

episodes.subtitle: Philosopher Alva Noë on consciousness.
episodes.description: Philosopher Alva Noë says consciousness isn't in the brain.
episodes.title: Thinking Outside the Brain

episodes.subtitle: What it means to have a mom, what it means to be one.
episodes.description: What it means to have a mom, what it means to be one and the unspoken truths of motherhood.
episodes.title: Mother's Day Confidential

episodes.subtitle: New films on Youssou N'Dour and Australian sprinter Peter Norman. Featuring Olympic medalist John Carlos.
episodes.description: New films on Youssou N'Dour and Australian sprinter Peter Norman, who supported the raised fist protest at the 1968 Olympics. Interviewees include 1968 Olympic bronze medalist John Carlos
episodes.title: Portraits in Conviction

episodes.subtitle: Keith Devlin, math music, math dance and the discovery of probability.
episodes.description: Mathematician Keith Devlin discusses his collaboration with choral group Zambra. Plus dancer/mathematician Karl Schaffer, and the most important math discovery you've never heard of.
episodes.title: Mathematics in Music and in Motion

episodes.subtitle: Evolutionary biologist Marlene Zuk on parasites and evolution. Plus, parasite music with singer Daniel Kahn.
episodes.description: Evolutionary biologist and parasite maven Marlene Zuk. Plus, parasite music with singer Daniel Kahn.
episodes.title: Our Parasites, Ourselves

episodes.subtitle: Ry Cooder discusses his 'California Trilogy' and its latest installment, 'I, Flathead.'
episodes.description: A 2008 interview with Ry Cooder, discussing his 'California Trilogy' and its latest installment, 'I, Flathead.'
episodes.title: Ry Cooder's California

description: A weekly radio show exploring questions in science, culture, music, philosophy and more. Life as we know it, or would like to. The content varies from week to week and includes interviews, music and the occasional sound-rich story in the tradition of This American Life or Radio Lab. Produced and hosted by Robert Pollie at NPR-affiliate public radio station KUSP in California.
title: The 7th Avenue Project
